displayed_text: Patient: Mhm. Doctor: We always got to watch your blood counts, because we always got to watch your blood counts. And that means white cells, red cells, platelets, and then of course, liver and kidney numbers. But that's blood tests. So you don't necessarily feel bad from that. We do know that some patients, their platelets go down a little bit. And that in some other patients, you might get a little bit of stomach upset. So not like full blown oh my gosh, you can't eat anything. And if that is the case, then we would have to, you know, modify the medication dose. But you can get a slight, you know, nausea or upset stomach. So we'd have to figure out how that plays with you. Other than that, that’s about it, so it's basically another hormone pill. So Xtandi, tackles one pathway of the receptor. This pill is another pathway. They are somewhat related, but this is not a chemo, it's actually another hormone. Yeah. So we're just trying to make sure you're super castrated, and then some, and then some. Patient: There’s that euphemism for the Prius. Patient: So, how does it affect my heart? Doctor: So obviously, we have to make sure that we take care of it, it shouldn't affect there's no direct effect, you know, it's not like, here's the chemo and Oh, boy. The Xtandi is, you know, always has a potential for heart issues, because we can't say that it doesn't, because anything that touches that testosterone pathway puts you in more of a menopause and accelerates heart disease. But that's true with your, you know, Lupron, that's true for all the other pills you've been on. Unfortunately, that's the main sort of active drug with all of this with prostate cancer. So that's the tough part. This one shouldn't have a cardiac thing. But again, this is a study. So if you do have a worsening cardiac thing that's reportable, because we would want to make sure that no other person has that. Patient: So they don't know that? Doctor: Oh, no, this is why it's a study. I mean, this is- you’re guinea pig, once again, you know, like you tell us what's going on. But it isn't like this is a chemo or something that we're really worried that this might worsen heart disease. But it's always this- every time you fool around with the hormone receptors, you know, it can worsen heart disease in general. So I don't know about this particular combo, but that's why it's on a study and not me just go in here, take this. Patient: Okay. Doctor: What else? Patient: And for how long does this study last? Doctor: As long as you respond, we keep going. So if you are side effects, or too much, or you're like, Listen, I'm just done, we stop. If you say my gosh, this thing is really good. And I'm doing great, we keep going. And it's we can't take the drug away from you. Sometimes that's to the irritation of the pharma company, because sometimes they want to get out after a year, but it's actually interesting. One of my other studies, somebody's been on two years longer than they thought, and they want to close it. And we're like, well, I'm sorry, my one guy's doing great. So you can't take it away from us. So there's that other option, but in general, it's you who calls it quits or that the cancer’s has moved on. And if that's happened, we got to stop. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Mhm.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You know? Because any new medication to your system you might have a reaction, allergic reaction, whatever. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: We just need to be prepared for that. Okay? Family Member: And that’s fine. That’s fine. I can do that. Doctor: But most of the time it doesn’t happen. But if it happens, I like to sort of be prepared for the worst. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay. The other potential side effects, there is a small chance of dropping the blood counts, which is something we will be monitoring. If you have a fever, though, temperature one oh one or higher – Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: - I need to know about it right away. Family Member: Right. Doctor: If you have diarrhea. If you have nausea. Anything out of the ordinary. You know? Skin rash. Things like that-

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: So and - Doctor: Okay. We’ll get a plan. Patient: So it was described to be by the nurses. It’s the last time they tweak the aim if they’re not exactly satisfied with the - Doctor: Mm hmm, it might be IMRT, you know sort of image modulated radiation therapy. Patient: Don’t know that. Doctor: Okay, so I can check with him. I know what M___s going to do is try to have you sign a form so we could see if you could be eligible for this other study. Um, it is a pill drug. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, a biologic, so not a chemo. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um many, many arms of this trial. It’s like the octopus study. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Where there’s a lot. But you’re basically taking a pill. There is a pathway that’s always screwed up with prostate cancer. This sort of tackles that pathway.

Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So we use Lupron Family Member: Shots? Doctor: Mhm. So people get hot flashes. People get low libido, can have erectile dysfunction. And sometimes your testicles will actually get smaller. People can feel more fatigued you sometimes get some weight gain. There can be some cardiovascular like, um like changes in your cholesterol. Let me remind myself though, what other medicines are you on now? Family Member: Cinepro for high blood pressure. Cinepro 1800. Um.. Doctor: Is it potassium? Patient: Potassium. Doctor: That's right. That's for the secondary causes of hypertension. Okay. Okay, so that is, so that's that approach. The third approach is clinical trials. And clinical trials in general are where we're testing some intervention to see if it is helpful or not. The two that we have for people who have biochemical recurrence, there's one that's a natural products. And there's one that is a medicine called a PARP inhibitor. Patient: Mm. Doctor: The mainstay of treatment of prostate cancer today is hormone therapy, neither of those two therapies are hormone therapy. Okay, so the clinical trials that we have would be doing, they would be giving you some intervention, but it would not be a hormone therapy intervention. So sometimes people like that because they don't want to get started on hormone therapy. Because if your disease progresses, you got to get started on hormone therapy- Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: -and sometimes people, you know, don't want to be in a clinical trial. And so these are, the three general options. Family Member: Out of the three which one would you recommend.

Patient: Just in general, I guess. Doctor: Yeah, I think you know, before you make any switch, I would say we touch base, have you touch base with our financial counselors to make sure that you're optimized with everything. I mean, you know, trying to think how old are you? Patient: How old am I? Patient: The older you get the harder it is to remember. I'll be 64 in November. Doctor: So when you qualify for Medicare, is it now or you have to be 65? Patient: I'm the lazy investor. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Yeah, the lazy, you know retirement guy. Doctor: Sometimes you can like sign up early for Medicare, because you've got health issues. Those are things we got to get straight before. Yeah. And then Medicare is not all just Medicare, Medicare has dashes attached to Medicare. Some of it is the prescription plan that you need to have. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So those are things you got to get straight before you do anything else. So we're going to be in deep doo doo. Patient: Okay.

Healthcare Professional: So fatigue is a big one. Patient: I have plenty of fatigue. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Family Member: You’ll be tired. Doctor: Yeah. Healthcare Professional: Um um well let me see. (Laughing) Doctor: Sometimes we see your blood numbers for your liver and how they function, sometimes that gets a little bit screwed up. Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Doctor: You don’t feel bad from that but some things we have to monitor. We always say anything with pills can affect your, your, you know your stomach and your bowels. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Doc -so that’s possible. You could get diarrhea or constipation – Healthcare Professional: Um hum.

Family Member: He didn’t care. Doctor: Multiple. Healthcare Professional: Excuse me. He did have labs done. Doctor: Yeah. He told me that. So the PSA is what? Healthcare Professional: Sixty. Doctor: Sixty? So here it’s sixty point four. (Sound Door closes) Patient: No. I want it. I want to get it over with. Doctor: Okay. (Laughter) Family Member: Right. Patient: The longer I wait, the more things break on me. You know what I mean? Doctor: Well. Family Member: Yeah, because we have a whole schedule of appointments. Doctor: Okay. So when are his, uh, eye surgeries scheduled?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh so I think that’s a trial. Uh I’m trying to think. I mean, we, we had a, I’m just thinking of one of the study nurses. There’s also some evidence that folks who uh have been on enzalutamide like you are, there was a group that started giving people immune therapy with enzalutamide, even though the enzalutamide was not working. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: They kept them on the enzalutamide and added this immune drug. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And they had occasional patients who have very dramatic effects. Uh probably about twenty-five percent of the patients they treat. So we have a trial. I’ve got to figure out if we can finesse it because you’re not on enzalutamide any more. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It almost would require us putting you back on it, having demonstrated it doesn’t work, and then adding this drug, which is kind of weird. Occasionally, however, we have seen men after testosterone because potentially you could respond to enzalutamide. I don’t know. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that’s a little bit confusing but that’s another possible trial. Patient: That’s the extent, enzalutamide? Doctor: Yeah, right. So I mean you didn’t respond.

Patient: - and then six months from not it could develop someplace else. Family Member: I guess that’s what I’m saying. Patient: Oh. Family Member: Okay, so I’m listening; I’m trying to take it all in. So at this point the scan is showing it to be in a lymph node, which you’re saying just from your own experience, no need to biopsy. You’re saying this is where it’s landed now, which is not to say it’s not going to in a month, two months, three months, land somewhere else. Doctor: Right. Family Member: So we’re still kind of up in the air because this is nothing we can cure because of the type of cancer that it is and there’s no option to remove the lymph node. I don’t know Doctor: That’s correct. Family Member: That’s correct. Okay, okay. So with him trying to maintain quality of life and, and, and, uhm you know stay upright knowing that he has this and that he’s against hormone therapy but also still leaning with the fact that there’s the other foot to drop. Doctor: Uh hum. Family Member: You’re saying the radiation is a viable option if that’s the route he chooses to go but your recommendation is hormone? Doctor: No actually open to both; it all depends on your current wishes. If your wish is to preserve your quality of life as much as possible for as long as possible – Family Member: Um hum.

Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: you know it’s not in his head, it’s here and that’s the only part that could go wrong. Family Member: So doctor he hears that it’s okay for him to be on that motorcycle? Doctor: What I’m saying is, for me, I don’t advise it. But if you say medically if there is some reason you can’t be on it, no. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So if he asks me is there a medical reason why I can’t be on it? No. Do I think it’s a good idea? Not really. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But you know I’m not, I’m not the one that can tell you. You have to use common sense. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s not like you’re going up north, you’re going to F__. Patient: Yeah, well Doc I went to C__. Doctor: I got ya, but that was way before you got sick.

Family Member: Every visit. Doctor: For some time yes. Family Member: And this would be like at first I know it’s super intensive with tests, but then does it go to once a month or is it always more intensive? Doctor: It does eventually. Yes. Yes after the first six to eight weeks. Family Member: But that’s a few months down the road. Patient: And you’d maintain the care? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: That’s very important. Patient: Okay and uh okay. Yeah we’ll look at the consent form. It sounds more complicated. Doctor: Because one side, yeah so there is – I think what I’ll do is I’ll give you the consent to read through and then we’ll set up a time to come in downtown with the potential for doing all the testing needed if you decide you’re okay with proceeding. Patient: And we were planning to go on a cruise in February. Doctor: Okay. That should be fine still.

Patient: I ain’t seen it in my lymph nodes. I check my lymph nodes. I ain’t seen none in my lymph nodes. Doctor: Well, you can’t see it. It’s inside when I do scans. So the good part is you don’t hurt or feel bad. Thank goodness. Family Member: Right. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So that’s great. But it doesn’t mean that we don’t do stuff because that’s why I check scans because it’s inside. So that’s, that’s why. Family Member: Um. Okay. Doctor: So that’s where we’re at. Family Member: That’s the proper response. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: And, uh, I’m still ready to ask. Doctor: Yep? Family Member: Oh. I ran into a lady.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - your PSA was a fourteen in September and then it was twenty-eight January. So in a four-month period your PSA went up one hundred percent. It doubled. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So based on that trajectory, if I had to guess, your PSA is still at the same place, so to speak, it will take about half that amount of time for your PSA to go about fifty percent. So if it goes - you’re expected to go up fifty percent … for a year, two years Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So that’s the general, overall, design of the trial. And um because the trial involves radiation therapy being delivered by a radiology oncologist. And would and the ORIOLE study as they call it, is being run by one of the radiology oncologists called Dr. T. You’ll see his name here. And, the way that we would precede, if you wanted me to, is to after we have this conversation… to give you the consent form, read it very carefully. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Um to arrange a consultation, or a timely consultation with Dr. T in his clinic, which is in the building. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: And, on that particular day you would have read out any particular information about the trial and issue questions for him and his team. Um, and if those questions aren’t answered to your satisfaction go ahead and do that. Then after that you’ve basically completed the screening for randomization. Okay. So although the study is a randomized study, it’s not a blinded study. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But in the case of radiotherapy versus therapy,

Family Member: Right. Doctor: Organs are good. Family Member: Good. Doctor: Okay, okay still got diabetes to worry about, not the cancer. Patient: So bone as in spine or is it now in Doctor: Yeah, spine as in spine and pelvis. So it’s right here. Healthcare Professional: So quit climbing ladders and falling. Doctor: That’s – I was going to do a drive-by and get his stinking ladder. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: Let her shoot you up, my friend. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, I’m going to get this rolling with Dr. ___. Patient: So it seems to me though that -

Patient: Right. That’s like I had before. It crippled me. I couldn’t walk. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: By the time there the next day they gave me some potassium and they gave me antibiotics. Doctor: Um hum. Um hum. Yeah. Patient: And was walking in an hour or two. Doctor: Yeah. And you were really dehydrated. Patient: Yeah I was. Doctor: So they had to give you a lot of fluids. So your doctor’s pretty, pretty worried. Your, your lungs, you know, they’re already not great with the cancer but then you had pneumonia on top of that, so. Well, we’ll get those records to make sure that’s, and you know, kind of what ended up happening because they couldn’t give me anything until you were discharged. So now that you’re discharged for a couple of days, they’ll send that up, up to us. Patient: Yeah, Uh the last time they gave me something to take home, antibiotics, some kind of antibiotics to take home, that just I didn’t get nothing. Doctor: Okay. You didn’t get some this time? Okay. So it might have been more flu. Yeah. Okay. So, I’ll, I’ll have M___ come in and say hello and then we’ll have you come back here in a couple of weeks and let’s, let’s run through it. Awesome. Glad you’re back. You scared me. Doctor: You take care of him. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And I’ll have her come in and we’ll, we’ll get you out of here. Alright. I’ll see you guys.
